title: Vintage Tobacco Tin typeface
content:
Hi all -

Can anyone possibly suggest a good match for THE GREYS / SILK CUT VIRGINIA typeface used on this old tin?

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150312164922im_/http:/typophile.com/files/IMG_0672_3561.png)
author: anniemack

comments.content:
Elements of Perpetua and Penumbra feel right, but it's the R I'm really trying to match...  
thanks!
or Bookman old style...sort of close...

Pre WW I spur serif design. Can't decide if it is lettering or was a font. I did not spot an obvious digital substitute.  
Scale is small but it may include an arrowhead termination on the goose-neck terminals of \_C\_, \_G\_ and \_S\_.  
The leg on \_R\_ reminds me of some Goudy fonts from the era, such as Goudy Oldstyle

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150312164922im_/http:/typophile.com/files/GoudyOldstyleAsGreys_5824.gif)
  [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/lanston/ltc-goudy-oldstyle/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150312164922/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/lanston/ltc-goudy-oldstyle/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/lanston/ltc-goudy-oldstyle/")  
Some general similarity Vertrina 
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150312164922im_/http:/typophile.com/files/VertrinaAsGreys_5784.gif)
  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/gatf/vertrina/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150312164922/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/gatf/vertrina/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/gatf/vertrina/")  
Possible substitute, which differs in many details, is a Mark Simonson recreation of a 1920s lettering style called Goldenbook  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150312164922im_/http:/typophile.com/files/GoldenbookAsGreys_6338.gif)
  [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/marksimonson/goldenbook/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150312164922/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/marksimonson/goldenbook/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/marksimonson/goldenbook/")  
Don

For overall letter forms, I think it may have been based on something like Goudy Medium (just raise the crossbars on the |H|, |G|, and |E| and rein in the serifs):  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/redrooster/goudy-38-rr/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150312164922/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/redrooster/goudy-38-rr/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/redrooster/goudy-38-rr/")

For general look and feel, but still missing some crucial details (such as the |R| and some serifs), these might also work for recreations:  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/aperto/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150312164922/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/aperto/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/aperto/")  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontbureau/grand-central/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150312164922/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontbureau/grand-central/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontbureau/grand-central/")  
 [http://www.t26.com/search?q=Glosso](http://web.archive.org/web/20150312164922/http:/www.t26.com/search?q=Glosso "http://www.t26.com/search?q=Glosso")

There’s also a passing resemblance to Korinna, which was designed in 1904 (the serifs are way off, but the overall form isn’t bad):  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/adobe/itc-korinna/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150312164922/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/adobe/itc-korinna/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/adobe/itc-korinna/")

Nevada Serial captures some of the details (especially the |E|):  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/ef/nevada/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150312164922/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/ef/nevada/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/ef/nevada/")

The Goudy 38 is a closer Goudy -- here is the Book weight

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150312164922im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Goudy38BookAsGreys_5992.gif)
  
Nevada is also interesting  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150312164922im_/http:/typophile.com/files/NevadaAsGreys_4083.gif)
  
Looking at the \_G\_ I note, in addition to the high bar, a small spur on the chin, a feature shown on Vertrina and quite a few fonts of the era.  
Don

The engraving or lithography used to make the lid design may have been made by an English craftsman who was familiar with a font sold in England as Wren, which has the sucking lemon \_G\_ with a tall bar and a small spur on the chin, and various similarities in other letters.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150312164922im_/http:/typophile.com/files/WrenLight@Klingspor@PrintingTypesP72SM_4803.jpg)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150312164922im_/http:/typophile.com/files/WrenBold@Klingspor@PrintingTypesP72SM_5452.jpg)
  
Don

Wren is the English version of Tiemann Mediaeval designed by Walter Tiemann in 1909. There is a digital version by Gerhard Helzel.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150312164922im_/http:/typophile.com/files/TiemannMediaeval@Helzel_4742.png)
  
See page 15 of his specimen book:  
 [http://www.romana-hamburg.de/Schriftmappe.pdf](http://web.archive.org/web/20150312164922/http:/www.romana-hamburg.de/Schriftmappe.pdf "http://www.romana-hamburg.de/Schriftmappe.pdf")  
 [http://www.romana-hamburg.de/Fraktur.htm](http://web.archive.org/web/20150312164922/http:/www.romana-hamburg.de/Fraktur.htm "http://www.romana-hamburg.de/Fraktur.htm")  
Don
